docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your May 31 Week in Review article overlooks a fundamental factor in the choice-accountability equation: health maintenance organizations control how their doctors practice medicine and refuse to disclose their treatment guidelines and doctors' financial incentives.
docs.abstract: Medicare Rights Center executive director Diane Archer letter says May 31 article overlooks fundamental factor in choice-accountability equation--that health maintenance organizations control how their doctors practice medicine

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Nasty, Costly Battle Shapes Up Over Changing Managed Care'' (front page, June 3):
docs.abstract: Letter by Dr Thomas R Reardon, chairman of American Medical Assn Board of Trustees, responds to June 3 article; supports broad range of protections in patients' 'bill of rights' legislation
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Nasty, Costly Battle Shapes Up Over Changing Managed Care'' (front page, June 3):

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: Martin J. Keane has spent two decades refining his skill at mixing custom-made prescriptions, helping customers sort through the maze of medications and making sure they get Feldene for their arthritis and Seldane for their hay fever, not the other way around. But that expertise and dedication have barely kept his struggling pharmacy on the Upper East Side afloat, buffeted as it is by the proliferation of chain drugstores and the relentless cost-cutting permeating every aspect of health care. Mr. Keane and his partner have tried everything they can think of. Pushing the $70 scented candles and $500 French magnifying mirrors they stock in the front of the store. Renting breast-milk pumps to working mothers. They've even considered mixing veterinary medicines for their customers' pets.

headline.main: Rebellion At Drugstore; Caught in a Cost Squeeze, Pharmacies Make a Stand, Rejecting Managed Care

docs.abstract: Independent drugstores are being buffeted by proliferation of chain drugstores and relentless cost-cutting permeating every aspect of health care; New York State lost 612 independent pharmacies and gained 513 chain drugstores from 1992 to 1997, mirroring national trend; some independent pharmacies in high-rent areas of New York City are refusing to accept insurance cards for managed-care drug plans, saying reimbursements are so small that pharmacists are losing money; in further blow to pharmacists, managed-care companies are encouraging subscribers with chronic conditions to order their medications by mail; some pharmacies are specializing, focusing on particular niche overlooked by large chains; one pharmacy has even begun asking managed-care customers to pay voluntary $3 surcharge on each prescription so it does not have to reduce its level of service; photo; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning at Giants Stadium, Giants Coach Jim Fassel gathered his players around him as he always does at the conclusion of practice, but on this occasion, Fassel did not discuss football. With most players on one knee, Fassel led the team in prayer for running back LeShon Johnson, a recent free-agent acquisition, who yesterday received a diagnosis of lymphoma, a form of cancer. Team doctors detected an abnormality after a routine chest X-ray last month and, in subsequent tests, determined that Johnson, 27, had a cancerous tumor.

headline.main: Giants' New Running Back Has Cancer

docs.abstract: New York Giants report that running back LeShon Johnson has been diagnosed with lymphoma, form of cancer; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Not long after Senator Edward M. Kennedy introduced a bill this spring to overhaul managed care, his staff put out a feeler to the unwitting heroine of the movement, Helen Hunt, the actress who portrayed the exhausted, angst-ridden, H.M.O.-bashing mother of an asthma sufferer in the movie ''As Good as It Gets.'' Would she be interested in promoting the bill?

headline.main: Nasty, Costly Battle Shapes Up Over Changing Managed Care

docs.abstract: Reform of managed health care becomes key issue in Congress, with some overhaul likely despite reluctance of Republican leaders; backers and opponents, including insurance and small-business lobbies, are spending heavily on advertising, lobbying and campaign contributions, mostly to Republicans; reform supporters say they want to give patients access to more doctors, right to appeal managed care organization's decision to impartial panel and freedom to sue for malpractice; American Medical Association, other doctors' groups back bill proposed by Democrats, as do labor unions; Democrats are reporting daily on Senate floor anecdotes about people victimized by managed care; photo (M)

CROSSMANN COMMUNITIES INC., Indianapolis, a builder of single-family homes, has acquired the privately held Pinehurst Builders Inc., Myrtle Beach, S.C., for $29.1 million in cash and stock.

docs.lead_paragraph: Chiding Japan for not addressing its economic problems more adroitly and voicing strong support for the International Monetary Fund, Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers warned today that problems in Russia and China had the potential to spread elsewhere. In a speech to banking executives at the International Monetary Conference here, Mr. Summers said the health and direction of the Japanese economy were important in the recovery of Southeast Asia and scolded Japan and its banks for not acting more boldly to help revive the nation's sagging fortunes.

headline.main: Treasury Aide Prods Japan and Its Banks to Act Boldly in Crisis

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your May 30 Business Day article on capitated medical care, in which health plans pay doctors a lump sum for each person they are responsible for instead of negotiated fees for each service, neglects to mention the most important argument against capitation: it is unethical.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Calypte Biomedical Corporation said today that it had received approval from the Food and Drug Administration to begin marketing its urine test for H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. The test is the first complete urine-based diagnostic kit for H.I.V. that does not require confirmation by blood test. The advantages of a urine test are greater ease of use and lower cost for health care providers, and a safer procedure for patients. According to the National Institutes of Health, there is no evidence that H.I.V. is spread through urine, thus reducing the chances of accidental infection as a result of needle pricks or the handling of samples. Like most blood tests, Calypte's urine H.I.V. test and its urine-based confirmation test both detect the presence of antibodies, not the virus itself.

headline.main: Urine Test for H.I.V. Wins U.S. Approval

docs.lead_paragraph: The amendment was brief, so it attracted scant notice when Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato helped tuck it into a bill he was shepherding through the Senate as chairman of the Banking Committee. But the provision, which weakened a consumer protection statute governing the real estate industry, was decidedly important to one company. Mr. D'Amato agreed to support the provision in late 1995 after lobbying by the MBNA Corporation, one of the nation's biggest issuers of credit cards. The company is also one of the Senator's biggest benefactors, having channeled more than $500,000 in recent years to campaign committees that he leads.

headline.main: D'Amato Campaign Fund Awash In Donations by Hopeful Lobbies
